newsitem.title: USA: WALL ST WEEK AHEAD/Earnings season heats up.
newsitem.headline: WALL ST WEEK AHEAD/Earnings season heats up.

text.p: General Motors Corp, Merck and Co Inc, Intel Corp and Microsoft Corp are among U.S. corporate giants reporting quarterly results this week to a stock market highly sensitive to negative news.
Battered by worries over rising interest rates, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 134 points last week to close at 6392, its lowest closing level since December 18.
During last week's slide, several companies saw that beating analysts' estimates with their first quarter earnings did not mean a boost to their stock price.
But any numbers falling short of the mark have almost guaranteed bloodshed.

"The market has sort of fished around within the data, within the conference call comments, to find some reason not to really embrace that positive surprise," said Charles White, managing director at Avatar Associates.
"But when somebody comes out with a negative surprise, the stock gets taken out and shot," he added.
Last Thursday Chrysler Corp reported record first quarter earnings but an engine plant strike overshadowed the news. Its shares ended the day up only 1/8 of a point to 30.

Disk drive maker Seagate Technology Inc fell 1-7/8 to 49-3/8 on Wednesday despite posting better-than-expected earnings. J.P. Morgan & Co Inc beat Wall St forecasts with its first quarter earnings Thursday, but its shares ended down 3/8 at 98.

Medical device maker Boston Scientific Corp, which said on Friday its first quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' expectations, saw its stocks lose almost 25 percent of their value, sinking 14-3/8 to 46-1/8.
Analysts said they thought most of the earnings disappointments have been taken care of through pre-announcements.

But market players said they will be looking for any warnings from companies that the stonger U.S. dollar has eroded the value of foreign sales, indicating profits in upcoming quarters will not meet expectations.
Analysts have recently cut first quarter earnings forecast for market heavyweights Philip Morris Cos Inc and International Business Machines Corp citing the impact of the stronger dollar.
First quarter earnings this week, accompanied by their First Call earnings per share estimate and the year-ago figure, include:
AT&T Corp - $0.69 vs $0.90
General Motors -- $2.09 vs $0.94
Merck $0.83 vs $0.70
Merrill Lynch and Co Inc $2.03 vs $2.03
Microsoft (fiscal Q3) -- $0.64 vs $0.44
((-- Richard Jacobsen, 212-859-1721))
